That it was just not. It wasn't particularly useful to be doing what I was doing. I was working for a project management company and developing. Developing pedagogical material and writing case studies and doing animations and doing all this stuff kind of like to support their trainings. So. So that's what I was doing. I was doing that, I guess, like, from 1999 to 2000, 1998 to 2003, maybe so about five years. Anyways, so in that moment, like, I was. I was just thinking, like, this is not what I want to do long term. And so with my wife, we had looked at going to do some volunteer work with a Christian organization which was called MCC Mennonite Central Committee. But I converted to Orthodoxy in 2003. And then everything came together in 2003 to leave. And so I basically converted in, like, at Pascha and left in the fall, which was. Just never do that. That's like the worst thing you can do. Because I was basically a new convert. And I was just kind of thrown out into the world. And there in Congo, where we were, I was able to. It took forever. I was able to finally find a parish, but it's really hard to access it. And it was difficult because of the cultural difference. You know, it's like all. Imagine all this cultural difference. You've just become orthodox, then you move to Africa, and then you go to an orthodox church in Africa. So it's really intense and difficult. But there are some very powerful, shining moments of my time in Congo in terms of orthodoxy that were pretty powerful. Anyway, so while we were there, what we were doing was working with artisans. The MCC Mennonite Central Committee, they started a project called 10,000 Villages, which was a series of stores all over North America that sold, let's say, handmade things from all over the world with kind of fair trade ideas, like ideas of encouraging local economies, encourage local know how to. And also preserve more traditional ways of making things. So that's who I was working with in Congo. We basically teamed up with a group. We basically created a network of artisans. And because export was so difficult to do in Congo, what we did is we opened a local store and then used a local store to kind of train the artisans in terms of terms of quality, in terms of design, in terms of also how to present yourself to clients and all that. Because it's hard, you know, when people are. Are poor and are. Don't have a lot of education. They don't. They. It's like they need a bridge, right, to be able to interact with people that are more highly educated and have more means. And so we were kind of acting as that bridge between the market and the artisans. And we did that for four years in Congo. We opened a store. We had about working with like, at least 30 different artisans and artisan groups. Um, and when we. So what we did is we set it up in a way with a local partner, and we trained that person. And ultimately the last year, like the fourth year, we. We moved out of the management of the project, became like, consultants, and the project just ran for that year with the local person. And so that store remained open until Covid like it. It. So that was like 15 years. So it was a pretty. Pretty powerful project. Especially knowing that in Congo, most projects just don't. They just don't. They. They. They physically, Congo is a crazy, chaotic place, but sadly, the store is in. Is in trouble because of COVID You know, it's just. They don't have. One year I was in the interior when Pascha was coming around. And so I was away from my. My wife for several weeks, kind of in a small. In a small area inside and kind of in the. In the Congolese jungle, I guess. And so it wasn't totally in the jungle. It's a city, but it's really. It's more remote. And so Pasco was coming around. I was. episode_id: SW - #209 - 2021-12-22 - How to Navigate Symbolic Interpretations - Symbols Patterns Hierarchies
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: So you always have to interpret the patterns as all together. And that's. I think I always tell people when you're interpreting a movie, for example, you have to stay inside the movie as long as possible because people tend to right away see something and say, oh, that's an image of Prometheus, you know, and then they jump out of the movie to now make these analogies. But, but it's like, wait, before you do that, why is that image of Prometheus used among all the other images that are there? You need to get that first before you tell me about something else. And so I always, that's my, always, my recommendation is for people to let the story tell you what its relationships are. So like, this happened again with. This happened, for example, in the Green Knight movie, where people would take certain aspects of the Green Knight story and then they would say, well, this is very. This is good. Like this is a powerful image of some powerful image. But like, okay, yeah, but you have to be able to account for all these patterns working together in order to really see what it's about and not just isolate one. And it's the same. So it ends up being the same with scripture. Right. Ultimately, with scripture, you have to kind of get to the basic pattern before you take a verse and you just say. And you just kind of put it out there. You know, a lot of. A lot of modern Christians, that's what they do. They just take a verse and put it out, and then it looks like it means something, but you always have to have it in balance with all the other stuff going on.

It was like, oh, this great thing where now all of a sudden everything is available and everybody can just say whatever they want and everybody can be anonymous and do whatever they want. And people thought like it was basically manifestation of a kind of anarchic freedom. And it was for a while. Right. But now look at it.

speaker: Jakub
text: Right, Right.

episode_id: SW - #209 - 2021-12-22 - How to Navigate Symbolic Interpretations - Symbols Patterns Hierarchies
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: Because extremes call upon each other. Right. Extremes call to each other. And so the idea that bitcoin will just be left to exist. And that's why, if you watch my conversation with. Actually, I think it's not out yet. I did a conversation with Robert Breedlove that's going to be on his podcast, I think. And I kept bringing it back to guns and weapons and saying, in the end, it's like, this will play out. The power of the mechanical state that has weapons is going to play itself out in terms of. Bitcoin is not just going to remain online. If bitcoin becomes a threat to the system, it's going to play itself out in the streets with. With real dangerous weapons. It's not going to continue to just be online. It's a silly idea to think that that's how it's going to play out anyways. I think it's naive. It's going to call for more control.

episode_id: SW - #209 - 2021-12-22 - How to Navigate Symbolic Interpretations - Symbols Patterns Hierarchies
speaker: Jakub
text: If people want to defend bitcoin, they will eventually have to do it in the streets. Right.

episode_id: SW - #209 - 2021-12-22 - How to Navigate Symbolic Interpretations - Symbols Patterns Hierarchies
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: I mean, I don't know how it's going to happen, but I'm just saying that it's not a simple. It's not simple to think that it's just going to take down the central bank. And like I said, it's like the idea that bitcoin is secret power is not necessarily something that you want either. It's going to reveal all these. So basically you have right now possibly massive billionaires. And if bitcoin keeps going up, maybe you'll have trillionaires, Bitcoin trillionaires, who are their only reason why they're trillionaires is because they own this coin. That's the only reason. They never built anything, they never done anything. They've never managed people. They're just people who bought this coin. And so is that who you want to rule you? I'm not saying the people that are ruling us now are doing a great job. It's horrible, and there's a lot of horrible stuff going on, but it's like, am I going to trade that for a bunch of guys that bought Bitcoin in 2011? Really? No, thank you. Seriously, no, thank you.

text: I think there is some evolution in your ideas about governance. Correct me if I'm wrong, because I remember you telling us three, four years ago maybe, about obedience to the authority, right. And you still keep that. But when Covid came, like, you had expanded this view on.

episode_id: SW - #209 - 2021-12-22 - How to Navigate Symbolic Interpretations - Symbols Patterns Hierarchies
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: Super obedience, if you want to know my position now, is that sometimes you have to disobey, and you disobey and you accept the consequences. That's the way that I see the saints do it. It's like if you look at the way that, let's say someone like Saint Maximus the Confessor, for example, he just said, you're wrong. He told the emperor, you're wrong, Emperor. You've got it wrong. And the emperor's like, if you keep saying, I'm wrong, I'm going to hurt you. And he's like, you're wrong. And so he cuts his hand off, okay. And then St. Maximus says, you're wrong. And the emperor says, if you keep saying I'm wrong, I'm going to hurt you. So he cuts his tongue out. And then Saint Maximus gets sent into exile. And it's like, I'm not saying that. That's easy, but I'm saying that. So St. Maximus never said. Never tried to get an army, never tried to raise an army to fight the emperor. Like another character in the Middle Ages who disagreed with his hierarchy, let's say. So you can see the difference between a revolutionary and someone who disagrees for the sake of the world itself, because that's what I think. But, I mean, I don't know when things hit the fan, like, who knows how it's going to play out because it's not getting better. That's for sure.
